title: Boris Johnson faces choice between election and fresh bid to pass deal
text:
But other reports said Mr Johnson was unlikely to restart parliament's debate on the Brexit bill and was instead girding for an election before the year's end, if he can get MPs to back one.

These conflicting reports suggest he and his team are divided over the best way forward.

Some are encouraged by the majority who voted in favour of a "second reading" of his Brexit bill on Tuesday night (Wednesday AEDT) - a result Mr Johnson made much of in parliamentary questions on Wednesday.

But there's no guarantee they won't change their minds once proposed amendments to the bill stand or fall during the "committee stage" debate. That could create a new Brexit limbo without leaving time for an election before the new January 31 Brexit deadline.

Others want Mr Johnson to take his simple election message - that parliament is thwarting the result of the 2016 referendum - straight into an election campaign, convinced he can win a majority and then ease Brexit quickly through.

There's some worry that Mr Johnson may pay a price among pro-Brexit voters for failing to meet his vigorously promoted self-imposed deadline of October 31 for leaving the EU. But others say these punters are sheeting the blame onto the opposition parties.

Mr Corbyn's team is similarly divided. The Labour leader is reportedly keen to fight an election. But others want Brexit out of the way first, because Labour and its supporters are divided over it.

Advertisement

Mr Corbyn's current ambiguous stance on Brexit risks alienating either a blue-collar electorate that supports Brexit, or else driving a significant wedge of its europhile voters into the arms of the Liberal Democrats. Or both.

The catalyst for making a decision will be an announcement from the European Union confirming the three-month delay to Brexit. This gives enough time for an election, tempting Mr Johnson down that path.

But it's also permissible to leave before January 31 if the British parliament does back Mr Johnson's deal - so there's still scope to push for a parliamentary resolution to the impasse. The problem is that parliament tends to shirk making a decision unless it has a deadline gun to its head.

Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar is expected to publicly endorse a three-month Brexit delay.

French President Emmanuel Macron has voiced scepticism about the worth of a delay, but tends to fall in behind Mr Varadkar, though Mr Johnson reportedly hopes he'll play spoiler.

The EU member states' top diplomats were scheduled to discuss the delay in Brussels on Thursday morning (AEDT).
description: Both the British PM and Opposition Leader Jeremy Corbyn are at a tactical crossroads.
